title: SEBASTIAN SHAKESPEARE: The hair-raising secret of Princess Margaret's mane
text:
She has already talked to former ladies-in-waiting and even consulted a psychic.

Now Helena Bonham Carter’s quest to give the definitive portrayal of Princess Margaret in the forthcoming series of The Crown has led her to track down a lock of the Princess’s hair.

This personal memento is, I can disclose, in the possession of Jean Pierre Guillemet, who tells me that he coloured the Princess’s hair ‘from 1969 until she passed away’ 17 years ago.

It was during one of the Princess’s hour-long appointments with Guillemet in the early 1970s that he asked if he could keep a lock of her hair.

‘Madame Tussauds wanted to make a wax model of her,’ he tells me. ‘They asked me what colour her hair was.’

By chance, Princess Margaret — accompanied, as always, by a detective — was that day coming into the salon which he shared with his colleagues Josef Braunschweig and David Andrews, who were responsible for cutting the royal mane.

‘I asked her: “Can I keep a lock of your hair?” and she said: “Fine.”

This personal memento is, I can disclose, in the possession of Jean Pierre Guillemet, who tells me that he coloured the Princess’s hair ‘from 1969 until she passed away’ 17 years ago

‘I don’t normally collect hair,’ adds Guillemet, who keeps the lock at home but brought it into the Ozzie Rizzo salon in London’s Mayfair — where he, Braunschweig and Andrews now work — so that Bonham Carter could see it. ‘She was absolutely delightful, absolutely adorable, very great fun.

‘She had a team of people from The Crown — the make-up artist and people like that. They were quite intrigued that I had a bit of Princess Margaret’s hair.’ But Guillemet is aware that the lock isn’t an infallible guide. ‘Like all natural hair, it fades,’ he explains.

He adds that when Bonham Carter, 53, appears on screen, her hair will be as close to the ‘rich brown’ favoured by Princess Margaret as it could possibly be.

‘It was fine, when it was done. I had the formula and used the same products; it’s much easier like that.’

Bonham Carter and her make-up artist picked up one more tip before they left . . .

‘They learned how to put tiaras on,’ adds Guillemet.

‹ Slide me › Bonham Carter and her make-up artist picked up one more tip before they left . . .

It's not often you see a Bond girl dressed as 007

Bond co-star is licensed to thrill as 007’s double

It's not often you see a Bond girl dressed as 007.

Ana de Armas, who stars in the forthcoming No Time To Die, eschewed the customary glamorous dress in favour of a black tuxedo and bow-tie for a film premiere in London this week. ‘Straight from the set of James Bond to the Knives Out premiere, almost impossible to do,’ said the Cuban actress, adding she was ‘in love’ with her Alexandre Vauthier suit.

One person not on the red carpet at the BFI London Film Festival was her Knives Out co-star (and 007) Daniel Craig.

Just as well. Their outfits would have clashed.

When the BBC dropped Jeremy Clarkson after he punched a producer in a row over a cold dinner, it lost a licence to print money.

For Clarkson and his fellow petrolheads, Richard Hammond and James May, helped generate £31.7 million in sales last year at the company which makes their show, The Grand Tour.

Newly published accounts for their business, W. Chump and Sons, reveal that the presenters and their director, Andy Wilman, shared a £2.1 million payout.

The quartet were also paid a basic salary of £150,000 a year each.

Under-fire Labour Deputy Leader Tom Watson has boosted his bank balance to the tune of £20,000 by penning a book about his weight loss.

The MP, who is facing calls to resign for his role in the VIP sex abuse inquiry, has been signed up by the same literary agency that represents J. K. Rowling, the Blair Partnership. Watson spent the summer penning the story of his 8st weight drop.

And in a new entry published on the MPs’ official Register Of Financial Interests, the 52-year-old has declared receiving £19,325 for his work writing the memoir.

Young models obsessed with social media might want to heed veteran mannequin Jacquetta Wheeler. She warns an infatuation with Instagram ruins the fun.

‘Where we used to be focused on the job and the atmosphere, we’re now constantly thinking about how it will be perceived by other people,’ she tells me.

‘That means you’re not actually present in what you’re doing. It takes the enjoyment away.’

Conde Nast chairman Nicholas Coleridge admits that using older women on magazine covers sees sales plummet.

‘I remember we had four or five quite well-known women in their early 40s [on the cover],’ he told Cheltenham Literary Festival.

‘I’m thinking of Norma Major, who was the first. We put her on the cover of Tatler but it completely bombed.’

Despite starring in the new campaign for Marc Jacobs beauty, unveiled this week, Kate Moss’s daughter Lila admits her mother has instructed her to go easy on the warpaint

Despite starring in the new campaign for Marc Jacobs beauty, unveiled this week, Kate Moss’s daughter Lila admits her mother has instructed her to go easy on the warpaint.

‘The best advice Mum has given me about make-up is less is more, especially when it comes to foundation and bronzer,’ says the 17-year-old, whose father is magazine publisher Jefferson Hack.

But that hasn’t stopped her from offering her own tips to the supermodel.

‘I’ve taught her how to apply highlighter in the right places,’ she adds.

‘Once, I noticed she did it completely wrong, so I had to correct it.’

Twice-married model-turned-publican Jodie Kidd wouldn’t shy away from walking up the aisle a third time.

‘I would get married a third, fourth or fifth or as many times as I want,’ the 41-year-old told me at a Specsavers party.

Despite being a supporter of equal rights, she said she would never get down on bended knee.

‘I don’t think so — that is up to the boys.’

Let’s hope her boyfriend Joseph Bates, 33, is listening.
description: Helena Bonham Carter's quest to give the definitive portrayal of Princess Margaret in the forthcoming series of The Crown has led her to track down a lock of the Princess's hair.
authors: Sebastian Shakespeare For The Daily Mail
